item.title: Using the tidyverse tidyr package to make wide datasets tall
item.description: Import seattle rain gauge dataset library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.2.1 ── ## ✔ ggplot2 3.0.0 ✔ purrr 0.2.5 ## ✔ tibble 1.4.2 ✔ dplyr 0.7.6 ## ✔ tidyr 0.8.1 ✔ stringr 1.3.1 ## ✔ readr 1.1.1 ✔ forcats 0.3.0 ## ── Conflicts ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() seattle_rain <- read_csv("Observed_Monthly_Rain_Gauge_Accumulations_Oct_2002_to_May_2017.csv") ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## Date = col_character(), ## RG01 = col_double(), ## RG02 = col_double(), ## RG03 = col_double(), ## RG04 = col_double(), ## RG05 = col_double(), ## RG07 = col_double(), ## RG08 = col_double(), ## RG09 = col_double(), ## RG10_30 = col_double(), ## RG11 = col_double(), ## RG12 = col_double(), ## RG14 = col_double(), ## RG15 = col_double(), ## RG16 = col_double(), ## RG17 = col_double(), ## RG18 = col_double(), ## RG20_25 = col_double() ## ) Display Monthly Rain Gauge Accumulations for Seattle seattle_rain ## # A tibble: 175 x 18 ## Date RG01 RG02 RG03 RG04 RG05 RG07 RG08 RG09 RG10_30 RG11 ## <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 11/3… 2.

item.title: ggplots for exploratory data analysis
item.description: ggplot2 package in R Created by Hadley Wickham Built on the “Grammar of Graphics” principles Core tidyverse package Every ggplot2 plot has 3 key components: Data Aesthetic mappings between variables and visuals Layer(s) to describe how to render each observation (usually created with a geom function) Basic scatterplot ggplot(data = home_sales, aes(x = square_feet, y = sale_price)) + geom_point() ## Warning: Removed 1 rows containing missing values (geom_point).

item.title: Data Cleaning and Exploration
item.description: This blog post covers the steps taken to prepare two home sales data sets for analysis. If you’re only interested in fitting and visualizing multiple models with purrr and broom, skip ahead to that post. Processing the data A single-family home sales dataset and a condo/townhome dataset for Garfield County, Colorado, that contain 2 years of data from summer 2014 through summer 2016. The data is publically available on the Garfield County Assessor website.

item.title: Fitting models with purrr and broom
item.description: Motivation Utilize tidyverse tools and the broom package to generate numerous linear models to evaluate how well sale price is explained by square footage for home sales in Garfield County, Colorado. A dataset is publically available on the Garfield County Assessor website that contains 2 years of data from summer 2014 through summer 2016. Processing the data See the first blog post for all steps taken to clean the data.
